name: James M 672
comment info: Each dot is a kind of butterfly, so less than half of the butterflies are thriving.  I understand that 20 years but very little of the species are in the green. Only 12 species are in the 75+ to 100+ and there are more than 50 types of Butterflies in the -100 to -75 range. Each year we lose 1.3% of Butterflies in the US so in 20 years if the rate stays the same we will have lost 26% of the butterflies population. Which means we will have 26% less butterflies pollination in 20 years.  This will cause problems going into the future. If the population of earth rises which it probably will in 20 years and there is 26% less pollination on crops, flowers and other oxygen giving plants there will be smaller harvests and less Oxygen which will cause even more problems. So we should try and make good efforts to raise butterfly populations and use more sustainable practices. So we should get off our computers and go outside and grow gardens and flowers, use less energy from the power plant and help bring more butterflies to our communities across the United States.

My takeaway from the following graph is that there are more butterflies in the larger quantity. My wonder for the following graph is how the butterflies decreased in quantity from 2000 to 2000. name: Tamara Sadik
comment info:
It seems as though most butterfly species have experienced a population decline within the years 2000 through 2020. The left hand side of the graph (shows negative change), where it is mainly crowded with orange and red dots. In contrast, the right hand side of this graph depicts a positive change, displaying fewer green dots as it progresses. Additionally, it appears that a few species were able to increase more than 100%, but that is very scarce. As a means to prove these claims, the graph displays clusters of dots below the 0% change, which shows that the decline is more common than an increase. The outlined dots represent the different species whose declines were statistically significant. 
    
    - I wonder why there are so many different butterfly populations declining
    - Further, is this a result of climate change?
    - Additionally, what allows the few species on the right to thrive, whilst the majority of species on the left to decline? 
    
    Butterflies impact communities around the globe. This is primarily because they are pollinators, which is a significant asset to building diverse ecosystems. Therefore, if the number in their population decreases, it could negatively affect local biodiversity (plants, gardens, agriculture, etc…) Within my own community, this could result in less flowers, a disruption to local food chains (birds and other animals eat butterflies), etc… 
    
    “Vanishing Mariposas: U.S. Butterfly Populations Plunge After 20 Years.”

name: Edy Reynolds
comment info:
1. I notice the abundance of orange data points, indicating a negative change in butterfly abundance. More specifically, I see a large number of statistically significant negative changes. This is very concerning, as butterflies are an integral part of our ecosystem, without them, we will be in big trouble.
    2. I have some curiosities regarding the graph choices and the story the data presents. To be completely honest, it took me a little time to figure out what the graph was showing and what everything meant. I don’t have a perfect solution, and I eventually understood its message, but as a statistician, I know data visualization needs to be clear. You can’t assume the viewer will interpret it the same way you do without some guidance. For example, a key for the color gradient could be helpful since it is not explicitly explained, and the color choice is not color-blind friendly. As for the story of the data, I am concerned. Such significant species declines are alarming, no matter the species. My initial assumption is that global warming and harmful agricultural practices are the primary causes.
    3. This data relates to my life because it could be some of my own actions that contribute to this change. While some progress has been made toward a “greener” world, clearly, there is much more work to be done. We need to start while we’re ahead, because the numbers are only going to get worse.
    4. Catchy headline: “Float Like a Butterfly, Stung by Climate Change”

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Edy Reynolds
    I agree regarding the clearness of the graph. I understand the gist of what the graph is telling me, but I definitely think they could've done things to make it clearer regarding the colors and the whole 2000-20 thing.

comment info: It appears that most species decreased significantly in population since the year 2000. The spread of samples thins quickly as it nears the 100% increase margin. replies.name: P
replies.comment info: @Erik Hi Erik, this is a very good observation. I was also very curious as to what made some of the observations significant while others were deemed as insignificant. I also wonder why the samples thinned so much as they reached the 100% area, maybe because more butterflies were dying than surviving?

Hi @Erik,
    Good observation about the spread of the samples. What do each of the dots on the graph represent? What is the difference between dots that are close together versus dots that are far apart? One factor that influences statistical significance is the size of the populations. For example, a population of 10 butterflies that increases by an additional 10 butterflies has increased 100%. But a population of 100 butterflies that increases by an additional 10 butterflies has only increased by 10%.

name: Zach
comment info: I notice there are tons of different butterfly species, and I wonder how can they quantify the number of butterflies in a species? How can they be confident that the number of butterflies they counted actually reflects the true population?

replies.name: V
replies.comment info: @Zach Hi Zach, I believe that when calculating polulations those numbers can't be super exact. But! To calculate specifically bug species, I know that entomologists use many different methods like malaise traps, pheromone traps, and light traps to determine the population in a smaller area. They can then use that information (usually something like # of butterflies per square yard) and translate it to a larger area, like a state, country or even continent!

Hi @Zach,
    Scientists use repeated counting methods over the years to get an idea of the population counts. That way, if the butterflies are feeling especially shy during one counting, they might catch them the next time they are out. They look for patterns and consistency to feel confident they have an accurate count. They also use different counting methods like @Vivian mentioned.

name: Katie
comment info: It looks like the population of many species declined significantly in abundance in the last 20 years. There is a population in the graph that decreased by more than 75%, but is not outlined to be marked as significant. How can that be insignificant?

replies.name: E
replies.comment info: @Katie i agree it seems as though that should be marked as significant, and yet the only species trends that were marked statistically significant are towards either end of the graph.

Good morning @Katie,
    Great question! Imagine a population of just 4 butterflies. If it increases by 75%, that only adds 3 butterflies. Sure, 75% sounds huge, but in a tiny population it’s not actually that many. A small change—like a few butterflies coming or going—could just be random chance.
    That’s why scientists don’t rely only on how big the change looks. When they call something “statistically significant,” they’re also asking: How confident are we that this change is real and not just random noise?
